author: jaccalder

description.text: I designed this holder for sewing machine bobbins, to keep them organised and untangled.

I printed this on a Prusa Mendel. I set printing speed low and layer height to 0.2mm.
I created this in Inventor, so I can't upload a .scad file, but it may have to be adapted for other brands of bobbins. I created this for bobbins with 20.6mm diameter, and it's a nice snap-fit.

comments.text: Worked great on the second try.  On the first one, I used two perimeters and some infill, which made the print too solid, and you couldn't easily pop a bobbin in and out without thinking it would break.  On the second one, used a single 0.6mm perimeter.  Perfect!  The bobbin pops in and out and the print only came out to 6g of filament.  Thanks for making this available.

This is a fully printable duck call. My son wanted one and I could not find anything here but searching the web I found these files on GrabCad which worked. This was designed by Doug Lanter http://www.RackEmCalls.com Original Source: http://grabcad.com/library/duck-call

Print one each of the files. I printed in PLA so the parts would fit together better (no shrinkage). The reed even printed and worked. I printed all at .20mm Layers and 20% infill and 3 shells except the Reed which was printed at .10mm layers because it was thin.   
I had to scale the image up and it could probably use enlarging just a tad.

comments.text: So I have the barrel, tone board and the wedge all printed really nicely they fit together great.  Just can't get a good reed to print, not sure what is going on.  Had one I thought would work out of PETG but it just won't rattle I don't think it's stiff enough.  Tried with PLA too but no dice.  Also tried tuning it a bit by moving the barrel around and nothing.  Unless someone can give some suggestions on how to get the reed dialed in I'll just go pick up some 0.010 mylar and cut a reed.  I'm not sure how people are cutting the k-cups? They're curved? Am I missing something?  Great post thanks for the project!
comments.author: 16by80

description.text: So, here's a number of ships we here at Ill Gotten Games will be releasing soon, these ones designed by yours truly in TinkerCAD (love that system!). For the Starter Set (currently in its Beta stage) head over here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:38130 Its a good introduction to the rules (subject to change as they may be). We've got a ton of other ships in the works, so check back if you're into that sort of thing! Also, anyone who's interested in designing their own ship and throwing it into the game universe, shoot me a message and I'll work with you on designing the rules for it when I have some time. Enjoy! -Arian Croft, lead developer at Ill Gotten Games http://illgottengames.blogspot.com/

Printed at a layer height of .10 with a 100% infill. The Class 3 base goes with the Smoking Demon, Tartaran Transport, and Star Dagger. The Class 2 base goes with the Arrowhead and the Tartaran Fighter. With all of these, you'll need a 3mm plastic rod to act as the stem for the base, though the base included with the Breach starter will work just fine.
These guys were painted with acrylic model paints.

This is a customizable blade for a shredder, like the one in http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:356580. You can set:
  • the number of teeth
  • the angular width of teeth
  • the radial depth of teeth
  • the pitch of the teeth
  • the nut trap shape and diameter
    To use with a CNC, download the file, and run the program with thickness=0. This should create a 2D file that can be exported to DXF.
    Currently there is a bug using number_of_teeth=3 and 5, at least in OpenSCAD.
    EDIT: Teeth now have more material behind them, due to a 4 point tooth.
    EDIT(2014-07-16): fixed (read "hacked") bug for 3 and 5 tooth blades.

comments.text: What number of teeth have people decided to be the most efficient? What are people using these files for, reproducing the metal version? Anyone guess how much these 8 teeth required for the original design would cost to have cut out? I'm interested in making one of the shredders but can't spend the over $400 to buy it from the designer, hoping I can source some equivalent or lesser parts for cheaper.
comments.author: cris11368

comments.text: To your first question, I dont know. I'm a physicist, and patent examiner, so I'm pretty good with theory, and design with a little bit of coding thrown in. My guess is that you want the space between the teeth to be such that it can grab onto whatever you're shredding. I would look at the shredder blades that are online, and decide based on those.

A Merman Model that is made from a bunch of derivatives

You might need to scale this model to fit your printer, and reasonable scaling should produce good results. You should probably print this with support material enabled, although if you modify the arm angle in blender you might be able to get it to print without support. I removed my support up with a pair of wire cutters and did some smoothing with a nail file and a Rotary Tool. Be careful on the hands as the fingers are rather fragile. I Printed with ABS White plastic Be warned this model is not open scad friendly out of the box; blender is the recommended editing software for this model. Yes, I am aware that one of the hands is at a questionable angle, this is easy to fix in blender; however, I like to call it an artistic signature. Likewise, this model could use some more refinement and segment scaling and smoothing to look better. Nevertheless, this model was designed based upon the fact that printing acts like a mechanical filter that will remove most of the joint imperfections; However, feel free to clean it up in blender. I like to run my printer slow and steady since my print deck has a tendency to dance around a bit so your configurations will vary. I printed it with the following slicer settings Layers and Perimeters
Layer height .3
Vertical shells 2
Solid layers 4 top and 2 bottom Infill
Fill Density .25
Infill 1
Solid infill every 6
Fill angle 45
Solid infill threshold area 70 Speed
Perimeters 50
Small perimeters 50
Infill 50
Solid infill 50
Top solid infill 50
Support material 60
Bridges 50
Gap fill 40
Travel 60 Filament and Temperature
I was printing with 1.75mm filament with a bed temperature between 95C to 110C and a hot end temperature of 220.

An upgrade for the X axis of the 1405 model Printrbot Simple Makers edition.
  • Expand the bearings to increase rigidity.
  • Move the drive motor to the center to increase stability.
  • Required minimum print area for motor mount: 80mmx147mm.
  • Multiple BedEnd files have been uploaded for various bed screw widths. Minimum BedEnd required print area will depend on BedEnd used.
  • Increase idler bearings to 608 size. Better match for belt width and more common world wide.
  • Build in (2) switch mounting locations for fans and power.
  • Built in LED receptacles to illuminate the power and fan symbols.
  • Can be configured as either single or double precision. For single precision, remove bearing on BedEnd and install tension block. Double precision configuration is shown.
  • Printrboard cannot be mounted under machine (where the X motor is now). Mounting the Printrboard in a well ventilated area will help protect the stepper drivers from overheating.
    • If you want to print the entire base I have a printable version posted:
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:442636 Important to note: If you are using printed plastic as structural machine parts it is important to keep them cool. I have included mounting locations for fans at the heat sources (Motors, Extruder, etc.). Care must be taken to avoid over heating.
    I have included a printable bed mount post if you wish to use springs. This item has a captive nut. If you are going to mount directly using heated bed mounting holes, the heat will transfer thru the screw and soften the mounting bracket. In this case I recommend clamping a 3/8" wood dowel in the BedEnd and using a wood screw to mount your heat bed to the dowel. The wood will act as a thermal insulator. In addition, some sort of insulator must be placed between the heated bed and the plastic BedEnd part. In the graphic I show a sheet of cork under the entire surface, but it is only required between the heater and the plastic. Covering the rest of the area helps to improve the efficiency of the heater.
    I have printed a couple iterations of this design and everything seems to come out as expected. I am designing my upgrades to the 1405 as I go, and have not yet completed the 1405 build. Concequently I have not yet run this specific design, but there isn't too much new here so I don't expect any issues. If you find something wrong or that needs improvement, please let me know.
    As always, feedback and suggestions are not only welcome but encouraged.
    The evolution of this design was inspired by discussion about expanding the bearing spacing for the 2014 Simple models. Thank you goes out to those who supported the effort with their ideas, time, effort, and R&D. I simply combined those ideas into a 3d model. Please review the conversation:
    http://www.printrbottalk.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=21&t=6860

Suggested mounting order on the Main Motor Plate:
  • LED's (if desired) They should push into the hole, than a M3 screw will hold them in place by the edge.
  • Motor
  • Idler bearings
  • Switches
    X axis end stop cable should be routed to the center, down the slot provided over the drive pulley, and back thru the slot in the diagonal brace. A tie wrap location has been provided just above the slot over the drive pulley. This should keep them clear of the drive belt and out of the way.

comments.text: I believe somewhere I read that 25% infill should be sufficient for usable printed parts. Is this correct? Would you suggest that I print these out with a higher infill percentage?
comments.author: thecrazytaco

comments.text: The infill percent required is dependent on how well the infill is printed.  A Hexagonal infill pattern re-traces the majority of the path on every layer and therefore is able to provide some support to the part.  If you use a linear infill the infill only overlaps every other layer and therefore is not able to provide good support to the part.

comments.text: Do you print your upgrades in PLA or ABS and is there a reason you would use one or the other. Because i was thinking about printing in ABS to increase the heat tolerances but is there a reason i shouldn't
comments.author: How2Texan

comments.text:
I print everything in PLA. I also now have a fan for every motor (except Z) and for the hot end, so everything stays cool.
Last week I had my first failure of a printed motor plate. It was my original GT2, X motor plate. Manually overrode the speed to 200% for a slow print, changed to a long fast one and forgot to change back. Next thing I know my X belt jumped the bearings and the bearings were way out of alignment.
Melted posts due to no cooling inside the X motor compartment and asking for way too much speed. Keep your plastic cool!
comments.author: How2Texan

comments.text: Printing very large parts in ABS is a challenge, I would suggest you need a large heatbed, that has even temp distribution, printing in a draught free space, and possible with an enclosed volume that can be filled with heated air. ABS has a 4-6% shrinkage factor as it cools, which while that can be compensated for in the parts design, as your part cools as you print more and more layers, the temperature of the bottom layers is significantly different than the top layers, when that happens on a material that has a high shrinkage it will curl and warp. The bigger the part the bigger the effect. You have to keep the whole part as near as possible at the same temperature during the whole print. By contrast PLA has a 0.5-2% shrinkage factor, depending on temps and is strong and rigid enough to resist the pressure difference between cooler and hotter layers hence warp and curl is very much less pronounced.
comments.author: iamjonlawrence

comments.text: It's recommend to print in ABS for the parts that will come in contact with heat. There's no downside for printing in ABS unless you can't get warp free parts.
comments.author: How2Texan

comments.text: PLA is fine if you can isolate the hot parts, the two main sources of heat will be a Heatbed if fitted and the Motors, in particular the screws that hold the motors in.
comments.author: MrCamil

Just a minor refinement to the standard Wade's Extruder. In the normal configuration, the screws that mount the extruder are inaccessible when the stepper motor is installed. This version adds inset hexes to capture a standard M5 bolt head (or nut), making installation simple.
This is the extruder block only, download the other parts from the original Wade's extruder page.
Uses any standard M5 bolt (or nut) that is 8mm across the flats (see picture). Socket Cap screws would still work fine with this design as well.

comments.text: I like this and want to print it.. but is it just me or are you missing a hole?
comments.author: MMendel

comments.text: Maybe I'm dense or its too late to the think straight... but how does this make it easier to install?  The screws still look inaccessible.
comments.author: tbuser

comments.text: The screws are inaccessible, but since they are trapped, they won't turn when you tighten the nut. You obviously can't torque the nut super tight since the bolt is only held by plastic, but it should handle enough torque to hold the extruder reliably.
comments.author: tbuser

comments.text: But the nuts are also captive in the Mendel carriage, so you then can't turn either.
comments.author: kludgineer

comments.text: Ah, I see how that could be a problem. I'm not using a Mendel, so didn't know that. :-)
comments.author: nophead

comments.text: To clarify, this would work for Mendel users since the standard socket cap screw will fit withing the inset for the nut head. It doesn't add anything to the standard mount, but it is not incompatible.

description.text: The D-Pad on the XBox controller can trigger two directions together, e.g. for diagonal movement. In the games I play each of the directions has its own function and it can be really annoying to trigger stuff you don't want to. Hence I have designed a replacement with dedicated buttons for each direction.
Take the controller apart and remove the d-pad assembly. Remove all the plastic from the inside the d-pad hole. The Thing will just drop in place and the controller can be reassembled.

comments.author: TakeItAndRun

comments.text:
There's a few problems:
1) The blade needs to be an airfoil shape. But something that is very thin. You can actually cheat this and it'll be more effective - make it a 1-layer-thick sheet, with a narrow ridge down the straight edge of it. No curvature required, it can be boxy and still work just fine (the reason it's more effective is it will generate the leading edge vortex you need while requiring less material to do so)
2) Make it big. Flying objects are all about surface area vs volume. So big will have to compensate for thin, since you're limited to something that is probably .2mm thick.

title: Ord Bot Y-Axis Rack and Pinion

description.text: So it has been a couple of months since I completed my leadscrew upgrade to my x-axis and so far it is still working good. I was going to do a similar leadscrew upgrade to my Y-Axis, but my leadscrew supplier, Trinity Labs, has closed their doors. As a result I have decided to try another method that has been interesting me for a couple of months after seeing some positive results on thingiverse. Recently I purchased a small 12' acetal rack and spur gear from SDP/SI. The idea is to hard mount the Y-Axis motor directly underneath the heated bed and design a way to hard mount the rack to the aluminum plate. Then i will use the motor and spur gear to drive the build plate. Does anyone have any experience with this kind of drive mechanism. I have attached a mock-up of my concept. The yellow parts are printed. Basically a mount for the rack I purchased. I plan on using tension pins to hold the rack in the mount. The mount will use the same screws I used to attach the heated build platform. Here is a video of it working. http://youtu.be/pcQ9hYwiU5A

SDP/SI
Part Number Description Sell Unit Price
S10Z05M028T0505 Module 0.5, 28 Teeth, 20° Pressure Angle, Acetal / Stainless Steel Hub Spur Gear Each $22.93
A1M12MYZ0525A Module 0.5, 20 (Deg) Pressure Angle, Acetal (Molded) Rack Each $3.38
Everything else is M5 T-Slot Nuts with M5x8 Screws

comments.text: Interesting project! What's your experience so far with regards to precision and most importantly backlash? Is it on par or better than the belt drive? How does the resoltuion compare?
comments.author: tarjeik

comments.text: My experience so far is that the precision is better than the belt drive.  My circles come out almost perfect and I dont have to worry about stretch.  I have heard people have issues with backlash but I think because I used a molded acetal part with such a small pitch to actually drive the access, I have seen minimal wear with very little backlash.  I have the added bonus of being able to remove my Y-Axis fairly easy without having to disconnect the belt or loosen the belt tensioner.  The only thing I still have left to do is rewire the cables, but if you are starting out from a new build it would be very easy.
comments.author: tarjeik

author: dagba

title: Replacement Power Supply for Printrbot Simple

description.text: This thing contains covers for making a replacement power supply for a Printrbot Simple (and possibly other) printers.

The hardware for this thing requires:
=============
  • 12V 20A LED PSU
  • switch of appropriate voltage
  • one dead or dying Printrbot Simple PSU
  • (3) M3x5 bolts
    Instructions:
    ========
    1. Print the covers.
      Check your new PSU first. The dimensions used for the .stl files included are 99mm wide and 43mm high. You can modify the .scad file as needed.
    2. Cut off the cords from the old PSU.
      Note: if you don't want to destroy the mains power cord, you can buy a replacement cord from a home improvement or hardware store.
    3. Strip the wires from all cords. About 1/4" or 8mm is all you need.
    4. (optional) Apply a bit of solder to each wire tip.
    5. Insert the wires through the power-side cover.
    6. Attach the mains wires to the left-side terminals.
      Make sure you wire the mains correctly. In the US, black is 'N', white is 'L', and green is ground. Check with an electronics expert if you are not sure.
    7. Here's the tricky part. Determine which wire on the printer-side cable is positive. Use a multimeter or continuity tester to find which wire is connected to the center pole of the plug. This is positive. Attach that to the V+ on the right side of the power supply and the other to the V-.
    8. If you decide to use a switch, wire the 'L' (load) wire through the switch.
    9. Test fit the power-side cover and adjust the cords so that the cover can be secured without force.
      Hint: Hold the wires and slide the cover toward the PSU. When it just about touches, you're good.
      Optional: Secure the wires on the inside of the cover with zip ties (you can wait to do this once you have everything hooked up).
    10. Attach the covers, apply nifty rubber feet to the bottom of the covers and you're done!
      WAIT!
      =====
      Always test your work! Use a multimeter to make sure you are getting 12V out of the printer-side connector and that the center pole is positive. That is, the red lead on your multimeter is inserted into the center hole and the black lead is touching the outer metal band of the plug. If you see positive 12V, you're good. If you see negative voltage, you've got the wires reversed - go back and fix that then retest it.

comments.text: Just a note, it does not really matter, but you have wiring wrong, in US and Canada live wires are coloured (black if single phase) and neutral is always white. Ground is green.
comments.author: svalsorim

title: Original Printrbot Plus (v1) Y bearing blocks

description.text:
The four Y bearings are attached with zip-ties which are hard to make perfectly snug. This can cause the print bed to skew when it moves in the Y direction. This is a part that fits over the two bearings on one side instead of the zip ties, and holds the bearings snugly in place.  
Just one is a huge improvement, or you can print two (one for each side), they are made to go on either side.  
The part screws into the Z stepper mounting holes and existing slots, and will require longer screws (M3 25 mm for the stepper, and one inch 6-32? for the other side).
Designed with FreeCAD 0.14

Desk Cable Flange

Anyone who uses 3D CAD software needs a 3D mouse!. I have the 3Dconnexion Space Navigator, and this Thing is a wrist rest surround for it.
It is in two parts which hold the 3D mouse in place to make it more comfortable and more like the premium models. Also allows access to the two side buttons.

Materials
-2x M5x40 socket cap head bolts
-2x M5 nuts
-4x 18x10mm pads (cut some rubber or sticky foam or similar)
Instructions
-Print the .thing or .stl. It is two parts that print together to self support.
-On Replicator 2, I used 0.3mm layer, 10% fill, no support , no raft
-As there's a large flat base, you'll want to print on blue masking tape to prevent it sticking to the build plate
-Glue pads on the base into the 4 recesses. I cut some 4mm rubber and glued with superglue. You could also use stick foam or something like that. You want to make the base really stable so it wont rock or slide on the desk.
-Insert your 3D mouse into the main body. Add the base and secure by dropping the nuts into the slots, then screwing the bolts in through the holes in the back.
Notes
-You will get some stringy bits where your printer prints the arcs with nothing below it. Don't worry, the printer will sort itself in a layer or two and you can just cut them off
-You could glue the two parts together instead of using bolts, though of course that's more permanent!
-You may have to sand down the edges around the side buttons slightly to give good access for pressing

comments.text:
Are there problems with printing?
The two pieces are printed at once and nested. Will there be problems seperating the parts?
comments.author: dere

comments.text: It worked perfectly for me. The lower part provides support for main part so you don't need to add supports to the print, so you get a better fit and finish.

description.text:
This is a simple and light weight fan mount for an 30x30mm fan, to cool the printhead holder, peak isolator & hot end isolator coupler to prevent heating up which often results in the filament getting stuck in the hot end.
(Mocked up the foto's since I already installed a E3D-v6 head)

Simple attachment by unscrewing two long bold that go through the head.First put on a hex nut on both the long bolds when partially inserted into the head, and then put the fan mount on the two long bolds. Then screw everything together again. Use the hex nuts to tighten the fan mount.
The fan has to be connected to an always on 12V supply (when using a 12V fan of course :-) using the extra wires for the second heater nozzle thermocouple. Pick two wires and connect them to the GND and 12V. My Ultimaker has a 19V supply, I just carefully soldered a wire to the output of the 7812 regulator.
Don't wire the fan to the print cooler fan since it is not always on. The head fan needs to be always on to keep cooling the middle section of the head after a print, preventing the filament from getting stuck.

description.text: The design files for this thing have been removed as a protest against Stratasys after their decision to file a patent infringement lawsuit against Microboards Technology. Their decision is extremely destructive and also underlines that the patent system is obsolete as it no longer serves any purpose for the betterment of society. Its main role is as a blunt weapon used by incumbents to hamper innovation. I see absolutely no reason to continue indirectly supporting Stratasys by providing free content to Thingiverse.
Valve for obstructing fluid flow without making contact with the fluid itself. This type of valve is typically used in bioprocessing, medical equipment and in the food industry.

This design uses a GS-D9025 micro servo that has been modified for full rotation and DC drive. 1) Print the 5 parts.
2) Attach the part "pv_a" to the servo.
3) Mount a M8 hex head bolt in part "pv_a" and attach the retainer ring ("pv_d") using acetone glue.
4) Mount a M8 hex nut inside "pv_c" and attach the retainer ring ("pv_e") with acetone glue.
5) Mount the servo+pv_a/d/c/e assembly in part "pv_b" (ps. it's a tight squeeze :)).
6) Fasten the servo to "pv_b" with screws.
7) (Optionally) attach limit switches. The design uses standard arcade-style switches. Hook up the servo and switches to your microcontroller and driver circuitry of choice, Insert a tube between the "pointy bits" - and pinch away ! I have uploaded a video to YouTube that demonstrates the operation of the valve (http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mUHaso6QWVU)

This is another NEMA14 stepper motor fan mount. I specifically wanted one for my Solidoodle2 because the x-axis motor gets very hot but I wasn't satisfied with the other two things I found on here. One didn't have any holes for the air to actually come out on top and the other was to asymmetric for me.
So, here is my take on it.
I will try to improve the airflow still because even now there is not much coming through. Maybe anybody has suggestions how to improve this without increasing the footprint too much?

I printed it with .3mm resolution and 20% infill (ABS). No support needed.
Just screw the fan to the bottom. To power the fan I used one of the 12V pins on the Solidoodle board. If you want you can add some heat sinks to the sides of the motor to improve cooling.

EDIT: Presently I really think this object is unnecessary for Blender. The "graph paper" in the background of Blender is 1mm and if you zoom out 'till the 10x grid shows up that grid is 10mm, and if you zoom out juust a little further you'll be looking at a 100mm box. Fit your model in that and it's cupcake-ready. One of the difficulties of designing models for 3D printing is a lack of a "frame of reference" to show how big something can get before the printer won't print it. To remedy this I made a cube, scaled it to the printable volume of the MakerBot (100mm on a side) and made it slightly thick so it could be printed. The Blender file has also been provided so 3D designers can scale their objects "to fit" in the build area.

Download, use as a reference. Printing this should work (it fits inside the build area of the MakerBot), and doing so will provide a sort of "3D picture frame" to put around objects to see if they'll fit in the build area for replication. (This is a bit of a silly feature but without it this object doesn't quite fit on Thingiverse.)

Solves the following problems:
  • mounted horizontally to improve clearance
  • prevents motor collision on left side at 0mm X above ~50mm Z
  • now only collides frame on right if you go past 160mm X and above 90mm Z
  • hot end now centered in carriage
  • can now be removed from carriage without having to dissasemble first
  • makes it look like a miniature version of Adrian\'s extruder (hey it's a feature to me!)

The front mounting screw is inset so that the large gear can pass over it.  That means you have to use an M4x10 cap screw instead of a M4x15 otherwise it will go through and run into the X bar.  (I just used my dremel to make my screw shorter)

_ fan duct 1.4 to be printed with 0.4 extruder

Prévu pour l' excellent extrudeur de Riku Rusanen : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:201184.
L' épaisseur de la buse a été augmentée en vue de faciliter l' impression. Le surpoids devrait être négligeable.

Printed and tested. All OK, the location is perfect to blow on the PLA without cooling down the brass part of the extruder.
I get a very nice result by printing it slowly but as previously told, the thickness of the duct has been increased and a higher speed can be selected.
Pièce imprimée et testé OK. La localisation de l' extrémité de la buse est parfaite pour souffler sur le PLA sans refroidir la partie chauffante de l' extrudeur.
J' ai obtenu un bon résultat en imprimant lentement mais comme dit plus haut, l' épaisseur de la buse a été augmentée et une vitesse bien supérieure pourrait être utilisée.

For attaching to the top of your Prusa to light your print bed.

1)Print (I did two) 2)Calculate the size of resistor you need using the following formula
R = (V1 - V2) / I where:
V1 = supply voltage
V2 = LED voltage
I = LED current
(I used 6 LEDs, each at 30mA, therefore: 6 * 30 =180mA, so my value for I is 00.180)
My formula looked like:
(5-3.3)/00.180 = 9.4 A, so I used a 10 ohm Resistor 3)Solder together 6 LEDs into two groups of 3. Make sure they are equal distance apart for the holes. (I flipped the Light bar upside down and inserted the LEDs backwards, so as to hold them in place for soldering. I then soldered the leads together.) 4) solder the 2 Lightbars together using 2 strands of wire. Make sure that the Positive from one goes to the Positive of the other. 5)Solder 1 wire from a power supply to a 10 ohm resistor to the positive side of the Lightbars.
solder a ground wire to the negative side of the Lightbars. 6) Attach the Lightbars to the top of your Prusa using some zip-ties. 7)Make sure there are no short circuits, and plug the Lightbars into a power supply. 8) Turn on and enjoy a nicely lit Printer **To Make changes to the OpenSCAD file you need the LED Module found here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:38396

comments.text: I like the this bar, simple and effective. But LEDs should not share a single resistor when wired in parallel. Instead each LED needs it own current limiting resistor. So I used a 12v power source, with LEDs on each bar in serie, sharing a common 110 Ohms resistor on the cathode of the last resistor. I made two bars wired in parallel.

title: Smart phone holder with xyz couplings

description.text:
It's a mobile phone holder with couplings in xyz directions. (Couplings: Z = M5 bolt, Y= M3 bolts, X = M5 bolts) This one is sized for my I Phone Four S. To resize it for your smart phones, try to change the OpenSCAD parameters. With this holder you will have many ways to mount your cell phone everywhere you like. But remember, there are many ways to damage your cell phone, too. Update V3:
Added a x-coupling with a plug connection. With that you can attach a vertical rod on each side. The thumb wheel is for a fast assembly and disassembling of the x-coupling.

Hardware:
You will need a 40 mm M5 hexagon bolt and two about 20 mm M5 threaded rods (depending on your phone's length) and M5 nuts. For the y-coupling you will need two M3 bolts with a hexagon head. The y-coupling is optional and can be added later. Print one holder, two x-stoppers and two x-ends. Insert M5 nuts into all nut traps. The nuts sit very tight to prevent shaking. Assembly of the Z-coupling:
Insert the 40 mm M5 hexagon bolt into the holder part. That's your Z-coupling. Note: the phone can still fall off the sides. So you need the x-stoppers. Assembly of the X-end and X-stoppers:
First center the holder on one M5 threaded rod. Then secure the position with another nut on each side. Then screw on the X-Stoppers on each side of the rod depending on the length of your phone. Note: you will be able to change the position later, because they are fixed only on one side (one threaded rod). Then screw on the X-Ends on both sides on the same rod. You need no nuts for the X-Ends, because they sit very tight. Prepare these outer channels by inserting a M5 hexagon test bolt. The last step is to screw the yet unused threaded rod through all the parts and insert the nuts symmetrical to the other rod. Note: The X-Ends round hole should point towards outside. You will be able to connect here 2 M5 bolts if you want to. Assembly of the Y-coupling:
Insert two M3 bolts with hexagon heads from inside to outside. The hexagon heads will prevent a rotation. Use two M3 nuts and washers to secure the bolt. If the print worked well, the Y-coupling should sit very tight on the holder's hexagon shaft. This part is the weakest coupling and may break apart by using too much force. Assembly of the X-coupling:
Use two screws and two nuts on each X-end as shafts. Then assemble the removable part. Use two M6 nuts and a washer on a M6 threaded rod as a lower fixture. Then put the X-coupling part on the top. Finally put a washer and the M6 Thumb wheel part on it. Done! Now you can insert a leveling tool (15 x 15 mm) at the top of the holder part or leave it empty. I am curious about your ideas how to use this thing.

At the scale and resolution I was printing, the struts and part of the vertical stabilizer dropped out. My eight-year-old son was satisfied with the result, but I wanted to improve it... . I pulled stumpwimple's nice biplane STL into OpenSCAD and imposed some changes on top of it: a simplified strut configuration for printing at lower resolution, and I also added landing gear. Ben, I hope you don't mind! It looks as though you had a specific prototype in mind, and I've mundged a couple of different "bipes" together in my remix.
At full scale with a .5 extruder it's still on the very edge of resolution for my hardware; scaling up by at least 10% would probably help.
NOTE TO READERS: If you want to run this thing, you'll need to grab stumpwimple's STL (http://www.thingiverse.com/download:445546) and put it in the same directory as my SCAD: I don't think it's ethical to push another person's code into my post!

Again, if you're working from the SCAD file, you need to put Ben's STL in the same folder or you'll get a bunch of irrelevant objects upon rendering. Grab http://www.thingiverse.com/download:445546
Also, scaling it up by a bit may help... my print was at the ragged edge of resolution for the current configuration of my gear -- got the wing struts but not the fuselage struts.

This is a fan mount for a Bulldog extruder, although technically it would work with any NEMA 17 motor. It snaps onto the back of the NEMA motor.  This is designed for a tight fit -- and it is tight, but it is removable. I included the DesignSpark file so you may modify it for a looser fit, or whatever else you need.  It is designed for a 40mm fan.   
The Bulldog extruder motor does get hot, which may lead to filament grinding during longer builds. This design helps mitigate that heat.  I should note that the Bulldog Extruders do come with a mount and built-in fan.  As you can see from the photos, my setup uses a custom mount, so I needed another fan mount.  
Enjoy

• Print without any infill for a nice finish.
  • Use 4 3Mx7mm screws to mount the 40mm fan.
  • Snap the mount onto the distal end of the NEMA 17 motor

This was captured from a SketchUp model found on the 3D Warehouse. Credit goes to saikindi for that model. I then scaled it down (quite) a bit in SketchUp to produce a model capable of fitting in my 3D printer, then imported it into Tinkercad to clean up the file further. I used Repetier as the printer controller and Slic3r to slice it, and had no issues with either software.  
The 3D viewer doesn't give an accurate representation of how the model looks when printed. The model doesn't appear triangulated or full of polygons at all.

Because of the large footprint and low overall height I had significant peeling problems on my PLA/unheated glass bed/blue tape combination. Because of the sloping and pointiness of a couple of areas, the hollow/mesh function didn't extend to a couple of the corners, which I believe had played a large part in the peeling. Despite that, the detail was pretty good, so I'll tweak some settings in Repetier and see if I can't make mine come out a lot better

If your Z axis on Printrbot Metal Simple oscillates/vibrates you can use this little bracket to fix it. 
It is designed to travel freely along the z axis (before using it on long prints please test and make sure it doesn't lock/bind on the screw or on the rods).
EDIT: included the OpenSCAD source for those asking to tweak it.

comments.text: It works ok.  Maybe if it weighed more it would screw back into the stabilizer, but it might do after it wears in a bit.

comments.text: Nice idea. But when it rises above the z-axis rod, it doesn't seem to screw itself back on when lowered (unless maybe I attach it to the carriage).
comments.author: mhelvens

comments.text: The whole thing should travel easily along the Z axis, if it's too tight it won't screw back in. It shouldn't need to be attached to the carriage. I wonder if it's the material or print tolerances, or maybe just needs some time to settle. The "nut" is designed to be flexible for this reason (the 3 cut-outs), and when it goes back down the lead screw should turn towards tighten and should screw itself back in (the base cone has the role of guiding the tip of the lead screw towards the "nut" - see if the resolution or overhangs don't prevent this somehow).

comments.text: It's only meant to prevent vibration, noise and damage to the Z axis during fast travel, it rests on the top of the screw and is supposed to travel freely. The Z axis on PB Metal has a design flaw since it's free floating on the motor coupler and that creates uneven Z layers, but this object as designed will likely not help reduce it since it doesn't restrict up/down (axial) movement of the screw, it is meant to prevent the exact opposite of that (the radial movement).

title: Ninja Feet for Printrbot Simple Metal

description.text: My Printrbot Metal Simple used to wander aimlessly around the desk. The desk also acted as a resonance box, amplifying the printer noise. So I designed these little pads, printed out of Ninjaflex and now the printer stays put and is much quieter.

I used Microsoft 3D Builder to print it but any slicer settings should work. Use a rubbery (no slip) plastic.
I haven't tried printing them out of non-rubbery materials, if you print out of ABS or PLA make sure you add some sort of non-slippery coating on the bottom.

Update: Even at 85% fill this puck is slightly lighter weight than another I have. It is also rather 'bouncy' and likes to catch the edge and roll. The material held up well to an hour or so of play with only a couple of the runners busting.

author: pwhervey

description.text: I haven't seen any snowflake designs on Thingiverse, so I thought I'd upload one.

Print, insert tea-light/light, see the snowflake silhouettes.
Obviously, only the LED tea-lights should be placed in a plastic holder, you have been warned...
I've also uploaded a smaller version that works as a tea-light holder or napkin ring.
BTW, if you are using Makerware and want to print a single border (a la Stretchlet) find the Makerware program folder, mine is in
C:/Program Files (x86)/MakerBot
and edit the fill.csv and jitter.csv files in
conveyor/src/main/skeinforge/Replicator slicing defaults/profiles/extrusion/ABS
setting
Activate Fill False
and
Activate Jitter False
respectively. Then print one of the solid models using the high setting but change the layer height to something quicker (i.e. 2.4) and everything should work. Don't forget to re-edit the fill and jitter files for your next normal print!

author: satgod

description.text: I started to design some slip-on "hands" to slide on the end of a set of disposable wooden chopsticks - to make it easier for chopstickers in training to get and hold on to food. Even when using Zydac's wonderfully springy trainer accessory @ http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5923, its still hard for beginners to line up the tips for food grip. But then I decided it was potentially wasteful to design a accessory for disposable chopsticks, even if the accessory itself was reusable. Solution: a full set of reusable, washable chopsticks! They have a large grip area that should make for stable handling, as well as wide tips for solid food grabs. DISCLAIMER: I can personally vouch that PLA is not dishwasher safe. It will melt and deform. Hand wash only. I would avoid using ABS as a utensil material. Here is a good discussion on 3D printing and food safety. http://forums.reprap.org/read.php?1,164077,167669 . I advise you to read it and use your own judgement before use.

Print, snap off the curl-control mouse-ears and hand out to your chopstick-skill-challenged little ones.
Now that I typed that, I realized that I should perhaps scale the design up.  No reason to age or size discriminate against the chopstick-skill-challenged masses!  Perhaps, coming soon...

title: Volvo V70 Console Cupholder Lower Part

description.text:
Replacement for the part of the console cup holder that drops down and supports the bottom of a drink. Should work for Volvo V70 and S70 models from 1998 to 2000.  
You probably don't want to print this in PLA; print in ABS or some other material that can handle being in a hot car.

As mentioned above, printing this in PLA is probably a bad idea.  
This is not a copy of the original Volvo part but it should be functionally equivalent. I tried to minimize the need for support but the axle pegs will most likely need them. (I needed supports for the pegs while printing on a Makerbot Dual.) You will probably need to press hard to get the pegs into the console; be careful not to bend the pegs too much.

title: Wrist Brace and Tensioner for Prosthetic Hand - No Support Needed!
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a wrist brace compatible with many existing wrist-actuated prosthetic hand designs (Cyborg Beast, RoboHand, Second Degree Hand, etc.).  It is printed flat in 5 parts so no support is needed, and a small print area can be used.  This design is also made to accept bearings for use in the wrist movement.   This design will fit wrists of many sizes with little to no scaling needed because it is held together by cables, giving it flexibility

All Braces will require two "side pieces". These are the pieces where the bearings are inserted. If you require bearing holes of a different size, I'm happy to supply the CAD files upon request. An average size wrist will also require two "diagonals" and one "tensioner". The "tension bits" are what the hand cabling should be fastened to, as is seen in other popular designs.
Once the pieces are printed, string them together using a flexible but non-elastic string or cable. Just one long cable can strung through all the small circular channels to assemble. Knots should be used at the end to keep it all tight. Enough string should be left between the panels that it can still bend around the wrist. Line the brace with foam for a better fit and more comfort.
If you want to use a different tensioner system, simply replace my tensioner with another one of the "diagonal" pieces, and fasten the tensioner of your choice to it.

title: Nexus 7 mount for a Spektrum DX18 Transmitter

description.text:
There are two files -- DX18-Mount-Nexus_7-no-case.stl, which is a mount for just a Nexus 7 (2013 version) and DX18-Mount-Nexus_7_45deg.stl, which is a mount for lazy people like me who hate to take their Nexus 7 out of their protective cases.  It's just big enough to slide the Nexus in with the flap flipped open.  
This mount requires no bolts or extraneous hardware.  Just slide it over the primary antenna.  The original design was parallel to the antenna, but I found it hard to see without tilting the radio -- which made flying difficult.  So, I angled the mount 45 degrees.

description.text: Scanned with the MakerBot Digitizer Desktop 3D Scanner

Sloths are awesome. Here's a poker chip-sized coin with a sloth icon. (Not legal tender.) Uses file "noun_project_656.dxf"
Converted from original SVG file
Sloth icon from The Noun Project
http://thenounproject.com/noun/sloth/#icon-No656
Designed by Gabriel Gomez
Public Domain

Print. If you want to swap out the DXF file for something else and play around with the icon size parameters, you can make whatever kind of coin you want. The Noun Project is a great source of design ideas. The only trick is getting the SVG files to an OpenSCAD friendly DXF (which is surprisingly hard on a Mac using Inkscape). I recommend saving to a .eps file and using pstoedit (http://sourceforge.net/projects/pstoedit/) which relies on Ghostscript. This is kind of the inverse of what tstrader is doing with the Many Coins script http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:37510

description.text:
Update,5th July 2014
I have fixed ear thickness as requested, I also took the time to add the cracks to the lips and smooth off some of the forehead in between wrinkles. I will keep both STL's on here in case anyone wants the really wrinkly version. See Last preview picture in grey, Left is older STL Right is the updated one, note cracked lips and more defined ears..
A request form BbrnKyle, the Mangalore from The 5th Element.
If I was to alter anything I would add more cracks to the lips and eyes, but I was thinking ahead for painting, and It would be better if the forehead and lips stood out more with a smoother surface, but I might have another crack at the skin later on.
Another one sculpted from a game character model (see second picture) it had a tonne of internal geometry like the eyes, inside of mouth etc, removed all that, gave him some clay, took it into zbrush and gave him the mangalore skin, hopefully it will paint up well. The other mangalore on thingiverse by lamerhouse was ripped directly from a game, but as you notice he didn't give any credit. I do not tag anything a remix if I find it was ripped without credit.

author: jalr

description.text:
This was made for a workshop at Knox Makers: Intro to Hydrophobic Surfaces. http://www.knoxmakers.org
Knox Maker Devin discusses the physics and chemistry of superhydrophobic (extremely water repellent) surfaces, demonstrates the behavior of liquids on surfaces coated with Rustoleum NeverWet, and describes some possible applications of superhydrophobic effects (controllably hydrophobic surfaces, self cleaning surfaces, etc.). Participants bring items they want coated with NeverWet to the Show and Share before the talk.
Feel free to adapt this badge for your own workshop/project. Can be easily turned into a fridge magnet instead by glueing/affixing magnets on the back of the magnet versions. Fabric-friendly badge version with stitch holes along the edge. Entire badge ends up about the size of a business card cut in half.
More info on hydrophobic and hydrophilic surfaces:
http://newsoffice.mit.edu/2013/hydrophobic-and-hydrophilic-explained-0716 This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/8aLk8lwpHQY

This is a parametric one-piece y-bar clamp. It replaces two y-bar clamp pieces from Mendel or Mini Mendel, and requires no screws! The previous version ran the risk of delaminating under stress. This version is modified to print on its side, as per Erik's suggestion, which should make it stronger. The STLs also have 6.5mm and 8.5mm holes now, which should fit the M6 and M8 rods better when printed.
Update: on the third try (I need a heated bed), I got this to print without coming loose. The size is prefect, the smooth rod is snug, but slides in without drilling and clamps tightly with very little pressure applied. I'll try to get pics up tonight.

The smooth rod goes through the rounded side, and it is pinched by nuts on the threaded rod through the side with the corner. Nylock nuts are recommended. The M8 version is for Mendle, and the M6 is for Mini Mendel.

These are another z-rod stabilizer for Printrbot+.  I made this data before mikemwa upload his one so I did not compare this with his stabilizer.  The holes for z-rod of my PB+ are loose.  So z-rod are not perpendicular and always wobbling.  These help to stabilize z-rod and reduce wobbling.

Print L & R.  12mm hole will be too tight.  File the hole.  Do not file too much.
If your z-rod is inclined like mine, printing longer sleeve may be difficult.  Print temporary version with low infill and install it.  Then, print actual stabilizer.

title: Kongotronic 3000 TIME DEFENDER Robot Clock
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
While no one has discovered a way to defeat our enemies the Chronophages, the engineers at KONGO! have devised a new weapon to monitor the progress of the time stealing fiends. Print your own Kongotronic 3000 Series TIME DEFENDER and not only will you never again be in doubt that time IS BEING STOLEN FROM YOU, but you'll know precisely HOW MUCH time! And you can help improve the TIME DEFENDER! There are expansion ports on the head that have yet to be utilized. There is a submission form upon which you can doodle your ideas. Build the ideas yourself, or send them to KONGO! and perhaps we'll include them in a future update. Be sure to "watch" this object, there will be updates. Like what? Well, right now there's a hook on the robot's back so it can be hung on a wall, but its tank treads are too long to allow that. Alternate legs will have be made. And doesn't he need a big ray gun to hold? Don't need a clock, you say? There's plenty of room in that big ol' body to hold other projects. Projects involving meters are a perfect fit. UPDATE 3/19/2013 - Now with Easter Bunny ears accessory
UPDATE 12/22/2013 - Now with Santa Hat - Can be printed without support (has a breakaway support built in, under the tab that holds the hat on the robot's head).
COMING SOON - PAPERCRAFT VERSION

Hey folks, I'm a freelancer. I put many hours into this project, not to mention countless meters of 1.75mm PLA filament, making sure this would be an exceptional Thingiverse contribution. Heck, I even created a faux package design so you can make a nice gift box. If you appreciate this level of work, if it puts a smile on somebody's face, if you tip well at restaurants, consider some form of patronage. Whether it's a few dimes, a few dollars, or a few meters of filament, I'd be very grateful. I'll even add your name to a patron list on this page. Message me through Thingiverse or my direct email,  "kongorilla at yahoo dot com" (please convert to a real address). My paypal account is linked to that yahoo address as well. Thanks!  
Need some modeling work done? Contact me for that, too.
PATRON LIST

A special THANK YOU TO Bluemetal for becoming the first patron for this project! davelandia - Thank you for your patronage!
Framingr - Thank you, too!
Trevor L from the Great White North - email me for a proper thank you! (I couldn't reply to your payment)
BigLazyB - Thanks for your amazing generosity!

All the files you need are in the zip file.
You'll need a quartz clock movement. They're commonly found in craft stores or in the cheap clocks you've got in your garage because you don't like them anymore. I'm not sure how standardized they are, but the three I found in my house were virtually identical (above is a photo of the movement I used). I'm anticipating some variation, though, so if the movement mount or dial doesn't fit your clock movement, shoot me a message with the specs you need and I'll be happy to make adjustments for you.
You'll also need a small amount of glue. I used super glue. I also used stick glue to attach the paper printout of the clock dial to the printed part it goes on. I was surprised how well the stick glue worked on PLA.
Printing and assembling the clock should be fairly straight forward, though time consuming. I've included instructions for assembling the arms because they have to be done in a particular order (see picture). I'm hoping all other questions are covered by the exploded view (see another picture). The clock movement and mount have to be pushed in from the back. 
All the visible parts have mesh topology that is subdivision surface compatible. So, if you have a printer that is much better than mine and you can see unwanted polygon facets, you can go into the Blender file and raise the subdivisions for the offending object. Hurray for virtually infinite resolution! This model will be useful for years to come, even when we're printing parts for our flying cars. I didn't use Blender-specific features on the mesh (such as marking hard edges), so the model can be subdivided in any software package that supports subdivision surfaces (pretty much all mesh modeling programs).

comments.author: EliteCow

comments.text: It's been a few years since I printed one, and my printer wasn't as "dialed in" as it is now, but IIRC, my prints were done at .2 using PLA. The latest feedback I've gotten is that the tolerances are a little loose, which wasn't the case when I first posted the files (back then, some people complained of a couple parts being too hard to squeeze together). Let me know if you have any issues I can take care of.

comments.author: kongorilla

comments.text: One thing to consider is I made this model two years ago, and designed the part tolerances for what I thought the typical printer was capable of at the time. If I were to remake it today, I might make the fit more snug on some parts. Back then, I got a few complaints that some parts were too tight and broke when you forced them together, and some people thought those parts were too loose. It's hard to target tolerances when there's so much difference in printer output, even to this day.
